{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3554064,"name":"Ryan","username":"ryan971","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/e495f1/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-11T15:41:19.049Z","cooked":"

My team has a custom-built router made by mentors in the ~2016 season, which requires manual tool swapping, and we were looking into automatic tool swappers. Has anyone in the past actually managed to build their own swapper?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-03-11T15:41:19.049Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":221,"reads":194,"readers_count":193,"score":1173.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":495159,"topic_slug":"has-any-team-managed-to-build-their-own-automatic-cnc-tool-swapper","display_username":"Ryan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":74233,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/has-any-team-managed-to-build-their-own-automatic-cnc-tool-swapper/495159/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3554108,"name":"Anand Rajamani","username":"asid61","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/asid61/{size}/7179_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-11T16:12:05.403Z","cooked":"

ATC spindles are affordable these days, coming in at $800-1200 for a 3kW 220V model from AliExpress/Alibaba. Jianken is a pretty common hobby brand I think. If you don’t want Chinese, Avid has one for $6k, and there’s a few European options for $4-10k.

As for the actual tool changing, you’ll need to plumb a pneumatic solenoid to control the tool change. If you look up Linux CNC ATC builds, there’s several out there. Most commonly people do a rack-style holder for their tools, such as the one shown in this video: https://youtu.be/98X_LPUHFn0

I’ll say that it’s not terribly useful to have an ATC given how few tools FRC teams tend to use and how un-headlessly our CNCs tend to run. It’s just not worth the cost of setup IMO (time and money), but it could be a fun summer project.

Ok thank you ! We are currently running a RegoFIX ER-25 collar/collet system which means we would need to swap out the spindle. I’m more worried about the Linux CNC aspect of the project. How would we accurately tell the spindle where the tool rack is? And would this enable us to have automatic axis zeroing? (right now we are manually zeroing all 3-axises).

This is currently router set-up for more context:

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-03-11T16:31:48.645Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":122,"readers_count":121,"score":34.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495159,"topic_slug":"has-any-team-managed-to-build-their-own-automatic-cnc-tool-swapper","display_username":"Ryan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m8s6-6CvS1E","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":74233,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/has-any-team-managed-to-build-their-own-automatic-cnc-tool-swapper/495159/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3554132,"name":"Kieran Jarvis","username":"KJARVIS","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kjarvis/{size}/209303_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-11T16:32:00.092Z","cooked":"

My team is also looking at upgrading manufacturing in the offseason. We’ve recently purchased a colombo ATC spindle, but most of the stuff we do can be done with a single endmill anyways. Nevertheless, fun offseason project.

If you’re gonna do an upgrade and you’re looking to actually save a significant amount of cycle time, pay attention to how much time is spent either accelerating or travelling. Our machine spends nearly half it’s life just cutting air. Like ATC spindles, AC servos are increasingly affordable from China. Unlike steppers, they emit a constant torque across their entire speed range, so you can get MUCH higher acceleration and rapid speed for a given power. There’s some crazy videos on youtube that show how much of a difference this can make. Might be wise adding a door interlock while you’re at it though, things can go wrong a lot faster (edit: looks like you’re already using them!)

Easiest way to program the positions for the tool rack is to actually jog the machine to all the locations. Usually you would add a tool z-offset setter for finding the length of new tools. You only need to do it once-per-toolholder, since the holder is always grabbed by the spindle in the same spot, unlike a shank in a collet. Typically on a router, your x/y zero is the corner of the bed for processing 4x8 sheets, and the z zero is the top of the spoilboard. You can program in offsets for things like tube jigs too.
